pr_title: Fix for RNTBDChannelPool task queue starvation

timeline.message: fixed latency issue and a race condition on close
fixed race condition in connection management resulting in creating more connections, fixed a infinite loop issue

timeline.bodyText: Both metrics below are not consistent right?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: ACK - renamed to *metric and added explanation

requestExpirator [](start = 39, length = 16)

timeline.bodyText:
New requestManager is created per channel. #ThreadFactorys ~ #channels.
Is this intentional?
For large outbound channels (ex: 6K parttions, how does it manifest?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: Not sure I understand the question - all new event loops are static - so independent of instance count, correct?
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

timeline.bodyText:
Clarification: Scheduling is to unblock timer-wheel right?
Thought: Leaving the choice to consumers is error prone, is it possible to force timer wheel it-self own and schedule on them (Of-course follow-up)?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText:
BacklogItem: gate the validation and detect future regressions.
Its a generic comments not just spcific to this change.
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: ACK - but let's please track this in work items - not in this PR. We need to make progress on this PR quickly to ship the hotfix.
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

timeline.bodyText: Is the move to do-while for readability?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: No - it is intentionally executing at least once (even if no channels available to allow for more eager connection initiation. Worst case we pull one pendingAcquisition task from the head and re-enqueue it at the tail. Can result in some unfairness - but from test tests we ran and the discussions/analysis in the last couple of days that trade-off is reasonable. Mo's comment above explains the possible unfairness - so I think we are good here?
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText: Is this same as above ensureInEventLoop?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText:
Its very easy to slip stream changes violating the assumptions.
We need a mechanism to guard/detect (in order of preference) for these critical aspects.
How about fail in our gates/CTL/perf runs at-least?
How about doing all our current validations with fail semantics?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: ACK - but I think we all agree that making the changes to fail fast will result in additional risk and need for validation (probably with changes to test infrastructure) - so IMO this is something we should do after releasing the hot fix. Makes sense?

One more I found useful is to list the channels and their interesting states (specifically the pendingoperations on channel was super useful).
It can be filtered on some threshold.
May be isInterestingEndpoint() can even be based on that threshold.
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: ACK - But i think we can decide that when we want to remove this additional logging. IMO for now we should leave it in here until we have confirmation that the hotfix addressed all scenarios.
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

timeline.bodyText: Clarification(non-blocking): Any idea if netty duplex channel support timeout OOB?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText:
RntbdClientChannelPool is a ChannelPool.
So far my understanding is its an abstraction facilitating the pooling mechanism. Haven't seen it coupled with the core netty Channels or handlers.
The attribute is a way of correlating it with the pool. Below mechanism is to purely ensure that release done on the same pool.
else case is interesting. Closing on this channel will only release the underlying channel but the associated pool state will be in-consistent.
Mi-targeting can happen if there are multiple ServcieEndpints for the same remote address, which means idle-time handling.
Lets not gate these fixes on it.
Please remove this comment.
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -1044,9 +1136,9 @@ private void releaseAndOfferChannelIfHealthy(
      * promise} completes with an {@link IllegalStateException}.
      */
     private void releaseChannel(final Channel channel, final Promise<Void> promise) {
-
         checkState(channel.eventLoop().inEventLoop());
 
+        // TODO: moderakh what is ChannelPool

timeline.bodyText: Did it help in any scenario or is it a defensive programming?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: Yes - removed the comment. There was one scenario where we ended up leaving a channel in acquiredChannels and availableChannels. This was part of the fix to make sure we don't establish more connections than MaxChannels...
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

timeline.bodyText: Please add comments on reason for "false' choice.
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText:
Clarification: Any idea on why the first channel short circuit has a different pre-condition (isClosed())?
Or why can't it be a simple loop and pick the one which is available?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: The is a comment in the short-circuit above already - to avoid an infinite loop in the close code sequence.
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

timeline.bodyText:
pollChannel [](start = 20, length = 11)

I like the 'safe' naming convention used for new code.
Worth adding that prefix for the same for other existing safe methods as well.
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText: nit: remove extra line
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText: Why is it pulled out of EventLoop ?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText:
doChannelHealthChecks interacts with the Channel and needs to be executed on the channel's eventLoop thread. This usually is a different thread than the channel pool's event loop thread - technically could be the same thought as well.
For clarity added a this.ensureInEventLoop (which happened already before - so just to make it more robust)
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

timeline.bodyText: Can these be made fully deterministic (like do either in the EventLoop or !EventLoop)?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

replies.bodyText: There is simply no need for this to run on the event loop's thread - but no harm in doing so either - actually for perf it is better to do this inline to eagerly pump pending acquisitions.
replies.author: FabianMeiswinkel

timeline.bodyText:
Much of troubleshooting/investigation context is fresh in minds but will have a high decay factor.
Thoughts on capturing that fully context in the code.
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText: Tracing the remoteendpint of channel will be quite useful during troubleshooting.
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText:
Concurrent select of a channel is fine right?
If so will there be multple release calls for the channel as well?
Will this looped over long time lead to un-intended overload of channels?
My assumption is the channel usage is guarded by the EvetnLoop so even the same channel is given back multiple timeback then it should be okey right?
With the same assumption and assuming that uneven load-balacing with-in limits is acceptable, then will a single queue and linear check of availability work?
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText:
+1 to this pattern.
earlier might look okey as poolHandler notification is very light weight and almost doesn't fail, but this is a pattern we should force in reviews.
Thanks,
timeline.author: kirankumarkolli

timeline.bodyText: nit: new line before.
